DataElement.preferredName: Soft Tissue Sarcoma Pathologic T Stage
DataElement.preferredDefinition: Alphanumeric code to signify the extent of tumor involvement at the primary or T (Tumor) site.

DataElementConcept.preferredDefinition: information related to the pathologic T stage of a sarcoma.

ObjectClass.preferredDefinition: A usually aggressive malignant mesenchymal cell tumor most commonly arising from muscle, fat, fibrous tissue, bone, cartilage, and blood vessels.  Sarcomas occur in both children and adults.  The prognosis depends largely on the degree of differentiation (grade) of the tumor.  Representative subtypes are liposarcoma, leiomyosarcoma, osteosarcoma, and chondrosarcoma. -- 2004

Concepts.definition: A usually aggressive malignant neoplasm of the soft tissue or bone. It arises from muscle, fat, fibrous tissue, bone, cartilage, and blood vessels. Sarcomas occur in both children and adults. The prognosis depends largely on the degree of differentiation (grade) of the neoplasm. Representative subtypes are liposarcoma, leiomyosarcoma, osteosarcoma, and chondrosarcoma.

Property.preferredDefinition: Pathologic; caused by or altered by or manifesting disease or pathology.:One criteria of the TMN staging system.  T refers to the extent of tumor involvement at the primary site (T, followed by a number indicating size and depth of invasion).

Concepts.definition: Caused by or altered by or manifesting disease or pathology.
One criteria of the TNM staging system. T refers to the extent of tumor involvement at the primary site (T, followed by a number indicating size and depth of invasion).

ConceptualDomain.preferredDefinition: the process of identifying a disease by the signs and symptoms (NCI Glossary).

DataElementConcept.changeDescription: 3-29-19 Received permission from Brian Campbell to transfer DEC ownership from CTEP to NCI Standards; tmt.

ValueDomain.preferredName: Soft Tissue Sarcoma Pathologic T Stage
ValueDomain.preferredDefinition: A malignant mesenchymal neoplasm arising from muscle tissue, adipose tissue, blood vessels, fibrous tissue, or other supportive tissues excluding the bones._Caused by or altered by or manifesting disease or pathology._One criteria of the TMN staging system.  T refers to the extent of tumor involvement at the primary site (T, followed by a number indicating size and depth of invasion)._The extent of a cancer within the body, especially whether the disease has spread from the original site to other parts of the body.

No evidence of primary tumor, in accordance with TNM classification system guidelines. (from AJCC 6th Ed.)

Concepts.definition: A primary tumor TNM finding indicating that there is no evidence of primary tumor.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: Status of the primary tumor cannot be assessed in accordance with TNM classification system guidelines. (from AJCC 6th Ed.)

Concepts.definition: A primary tumor TNM finding indicating that the status of the primary tumor cannot be assessed.

ConceptualDomain.preferredDefinition: indication of the presence and extent of disease.

One criteria of the TNM staging system. T refers to the extent of tumor involvement at the primary site (T, followed by a number indicating size and depth of invasion).
